item.title: Hello world!
item.dc:creator: ssun0032
item.content:encoded: Welcome to WordPress. This is your first post. Edit or delete it, then start writing!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Hi, this is a comment. To get started with moderating, editing, and deleting comments, please visit the Comments screen in the dashboard. Commenter avatars come from Gravatar.

item.title: Sample Page
item.dc:creator: ssun0032
item.content:encoded:
This is an example page. It's different from a blog post because it will stay in one place and will show up in your site navigation (in most themes). Most people start with an About page that introduces them to potential site visitors. It might say something like this:

Hi there! I'm a bike messenger by day, aspiring actor by night, and this is my website. I live in Los Angeles, have a great dog named Jack, and I like piña coladas. (And gettin' caught in the rain.)

...or something like this:

The XYZ Doohickey Company was founded in 1971, and has been providing quality doohickeys to the public ever since. Located in Gotham City, XYZ employs over 2,000 people and does all kinds of awesome things for the Gotham community.

As a new WordPress user, you should go to your dashboard to delete this page and create new pages for your content. Have fun!

item.title: Privacy Policy
item.dc:creator: ssun0032
item.content:encoded:
Who we are

Our website address is: http://164.90.154.73.

What personal data we collect and why we collect it

Comments

When visitors leave comments on the site we collect the data shown in the comments form, and also the visitor’s IP address and browser user agent string to help spam detection.

An anonymized string created from your email address (also called a hash) may be provided to the Gravatar service to see if you are using it. The Gravatar service privacy policy is available here: https://automattic.com/privacy/. After approval of your comment, your profile picture is visible to the public in the context of your comment.

Media

If you upload images to the website, you should avoid uploading images with embedded location data (EXIF GPS) included. Visitors to the website can download and extract any location data from images on the website.

Contact forms

Cookies

If you leave a comment on our site you may opt-in to saving your name, email address and website in cookies. These are for your convenience so that you do not have to fill in your details again when you leave another comment. These cookies will last for one year.

If you visit our login page, we will set a temporary cookie to determine if your browser accepts cookies. This cookie contains no personal data and is discarded when you close your browser.

When you log in, we will also set up several cookies to save your login information and your screen display choices. Login cookies last for two days, and screen options cookies last for a year. If you select "Remember Me", your login will persist for two weeks. If you log out of your account, the login cookies will be removed.

If you edit or publish an article, an additional cookie will be saved in your browser. This cookie includes no personal data and simply indicates the post ID of the article you just edited. It expires after 1 day.

Embedded content from other websites

Articles on this site may include embedded content (e.g. videos, images, articles, etc.). Embedded content from other websites behaves in the exact same way as if the visitor has visited the other website.

These websites may collect data about you, use cookies, embed additional third-party tracking, and monitor your interaction with that embedded content, including tracking your interaction with the embedded content if you have an account and are logged in to that website.

Analytics

Who we share your data with

How long we retain your data

If you leave a comment, the comment and its metadata are retained indefinitely. This is so we can recognize and approve any follow-up comments automatically instead of holding them in a moderation queue.

For users that register on our website (if any), we also store the personal information they provide in their user profile. All users can see, edit, or delete their personal information at any time (except they cannot change their username). Website administrators can also see and edit that information.

What rights you have over your data

If you have an account on this site, or have left comments, you can request to receive an exported file of the personal data we hold about you, including any data you have provided to us. You can also request that we erase any personal data we hold about you. This does not include any data we are obliged to keep for administrative, legal, or security purposes.

Where we send your data

Visitor comments may be checked through an automated spam detection service.

Your contact information

Additional information

How we protect your data

What data breach procedures we have in place

What third parties we receive data from

What automated decision making and/or profiling we do with user data

Industry regulatory disclosure requirements

item.title: What are vaccines
item.dc:creator: ssun0032
item.content:encoded:
What are Vaccines?


According to WHO, Vaccination is the administration of agent-specific, but safe, antigenic components that in vaccinated individuals can induce protective immunity against the corresponding infectious agent.  See more

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bglXkienTSk&feature=emb_title

A vaccine is a type of medicine that trains the bodys immune system so that it can fight a disease it has not come into contact with before. Vaccines are designed to prevent disease, rather than treat a disease once you have caught it.

Vaccines are a simple, safe and effective way of protecting people against harmful diseases.

Immunisation through vaccines is one of the best ways to protect you, your children and your community from the spread of preventable diseases.

Learn more about some common vaccines Flu vaccine Pneumococcal vaccines MMRV vaccine Human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine learn more Flu vaccine

Influenza disease can be very dangerous which leading to complications such as pneumonia, myocarditis (inflammation of the heart), neurological conditions and other bacterial infections.

The flu vaccine is recommended for any person six months of age and over who wishes to reduce the likelihood of becoming ill with the flu.

Funded flu vaccine is expected to be available from April but this can vary.

Pneumococcal vaccines

Pneumococcal can lead to a fever, irritability, pneumonia, meningitis, blood poisoning (septicemia), ear infections and other infections.

Two pneumococcal vaccines are available free under the NIP (National Immunisation Program) for specific groups.

MMRV vaccine

The measles, mumps, rubella (German measles) and varicella (chickenpox) vaccine can protect you against the following diseases:

Measles causes a cough, high fever, rash, ear infection, conjunctivitis and swelling of the brain .

Mumps causes fever, headache, tiredness, and swelling of the salivary glands, swollen ovaries or testicles.
Rubella causes a rash and swollen glands but infection in pregnancy can result in the baby being born with severe disabilities.
Chickenpox can cause fever, irritability, fluid filled blisters on the skin numbering from 200 to 500, meningitis, bacterial skin infection and complications in the baby if a woman has chickenpox during pregnancy.
The MMRV vaccine is a free vaccine for children at 18 months of age as part of the NIP (National Immunisation Program).

Human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine

HPV infection can lead to genital warts and cancers of the head, throat, genitals, anus and cervix and is mainly transmitted through sexual contact. HPV caused 70% vertical cancer.

It is important for women to continue to have their regular Cervical Screening Test even if they have been vaccinated.

Learn more about HPV vaccine? Click here

learn more

To learn more about other vaccines or search any of them, you can access health.gov.au/vaccines

See more in Health.gov Are vaccines safe? Vaccination policy

item.title: Homepage
item.dc:creator: mzho0025
item.content:encoded:
Understanding the
VACCINATION
in Australia



For your Kids

What are vaccines?

Vaccination is the administration of agent-specific, but safe, antigenic components that in vaccinated individuals can induce protective immunity against the corresponding infectious agent.

Learn more
Vaccination Policy

Do you know the No Jab No Play, No Jab No Pay policy?

Do you know the influence of these policy to your children?

More details
Are vaccines safe?

Immunization is a global health and development success story, saving millions of lives every year.
Vaccines are given to millions of people to help them to build a better immunity system.

Check here
Vaccination for Teens

Vaccinating boys and girls that protecting your child from developing certain types of cancers later in life with the HPV vaccine at ages 1112.

Read more

Most Important: Vaccination checklist for your child!

And dont forget to pay attention to the difference between vaccines

Here it is!

Here for YOU

Certain jobs and industries are linked with a greater risk of getting and/or transmitting a disease preventable by vaccination.

Please check here to know whether you have a greater risk of getting or passing on vaccine-preventable diseases or not through working.

FIND OUT

item.title: Are vaccines safe
item.dc:creator: ssun0032
item.content:encoded:
Are vaccines safe for my kids?

WHO: "Immunization is a global health and development success story, saving millions of lives every year." See more

Vaccines are safe and effective and theyre held to very high safety standards. Before a vaccine or any medication can be used in Australia it must be licensed by the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA).

The TGA extensively assesses each vaccine for safety and effectiveness. This assessment is based on scientific evidence. Vaccines are generally very safe but like any medication or natural therapy they can have some side effects. These are usually short lasting and do not require special treatment.

Vaccines are given to millions of people to help them to build a better immunity system.

Unfortunately, there are still many myths, rumors and conspiracy theories about vaccine safety.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iZpGjzEwlOA

[ays_quiz id='3']

Vaccination policy Vaccines for children Vaccines for work

item.title: Vaccinations policy
item.dc:creator: ssun0032
item.content:encoded:
Important policies need to know

- Do you know the "No Jab No Play, No Jab No Pay" policy? -

- Do you know the influence of these policy to your children? -


Here we challenge your knowledge by using memory cards. It's time to be prepared  !

[h5p id="1"]

"No Jab No Play/Pay" Vaccines for children Vaccines for work

item.title: Vaccination for Teens
item.dc:creator: ssun0032
item.content:encoded:
ALL you need to know about HPV vaccine

- A vaccine offered for both boys and girls -

What is ?

Human papillomavirus (HPV) is one of the most common sexually transmitted diseases (STDs). HPV is the virus that causes genital warts.Both male and female can get infected by HPV.

Besides genital warts, an HPV infection can cause these other problems:In females, it can cause problems with the cervix that may lead to cervical cancer. HPV infection also can lead to cancer in the vagina, vulva, anus, mouth, and throat.In males, HPV infection may lead to cancer in the penis, anus, mouth, and throat.

New research suggests that HPV may be linked to heart disease in women.Both girls and boys can get HPV from sexual contact that most people infected with HPV don't know they have it because they don't notice any signs or problems but the virus is still in their system and could cause damage. This means that people with HPV can pass the infection to others without knowing it.

- HPV vaccination coverage rate in Australia -

for GIRLS 62.9% 2015
for BOYS 62.5% for GIRLS 85.6% 2016
for BOYS 83.5%

-HPV vaccination coverage rate(%) by state -

How to vaccinate?

0 National 0 New South Wales 0 Victoria 0 Queensland 0 South Australia 0 National 0 Western Australia 0 Tasmania 0 Northern Territory 0 Capital Territory

The HPV vaccine is recommend to all girls and guys that from age 11 or 12 through age 26 to get. If needed, kids can get the vaccine starting at age 9. The vaccine is given in 2 shots over a 6- to 12-month period.

In Australia, students in years 7, 8 and 10 can receive free vaccinations at school through the National Immunisation Program(NIP). HPV vaccine is one of these free vaccinations.

Your kids can easly get the vaccination at school without any charge : )

~ get the NIP checklist below ~

The HPV vaccine is recommend to all girls and guys that from age 11 or 12 through age 26 to get. If needed, kids can get the vaccine starting at age 9. The vaccine is given in 2 shots over a 6- to 12-month period.

In Australia, students in years 7, 8 and 10 can receive free vaccinations at school through the National Immunisation Program(NIP). HPV vaccine is one of these free vaccinations.

Your kids can easly get the vaccination at school without any charge : )

~ get the NIP checklist below ~

item.title: Children vaccination checklist
item.dc:creator: ssun0032
item.content:encoded:
Vaccinating your kids on time!

- Check vaccine type that your kids' age group need. -

There is a checklist of a series of immunisations given at specific times throughout a childhood. Check the content below to ensure your children can get the best possible protection, make sure they have their immunisations on time, every time. The Schedule below shows which vaccines a kid should get and when.

Ps. All listed vaccines can get for free !!

  • Choose an age
  • Newborn
  • 2 months
  • 4 months
  • 6 months
  • 12 months
  • 18 months
  • 4 years
  • 1213 years
  • 1416 years
  • Choose the age of your children
  • Hepatitis B (usually offered in hospital)
  • Diphtheria, tetanus, pertussis (whooping cough) (Abbreviated as "DTP" vaccine
  • Hepatitis B, polio, Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib)
  • Rotavirusb
  • Pneumococcal
  • Diphtheria, tetanus, pertussis (whooping cough)(Abbreviated as "DTP" vaccine
  • Hepatitis B, polio, Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib)
  • Rotavirusb
  • Pneumococcal
  • Diphtheria, tetanus, pertussis (whooping cough)(Abbreviated as "DTP" vaccine
  • Hepatitis B, polio, Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib)
  • Meningococcal ACWY
  • Measles, mumps, rubella
  • Pneumococcal
  • Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib)
  • Measles, mumps, rubella, varicella (chickenpox)
  • Diphtheria, tetanus, pertussis (whooping cough)
  • Diphtheria, tetanus, pertussis (whooping cough)(Abbreviated as "DTP" vaccine
  • polio
  • Human papillomavirus (HPV)
  • Diphtheria, tetanus, pertussis (whooping cough)
  • Meningococcal ACWY
  • Side effect
  • Hepatitis B
  • DTP vaccines
  • Polio
  • Rotavirus
  • Pneumococcal
  • HPV vaccine
  • MMR vaccine
  • MMRV vaccine
  • HIB vaccine
  • Meningococcal
  • Choose a type of vaccine to check its possible side effects

Common side effects may include:

  • pain, redness and swelling at the injection site
  • mild fever of 37-38 degrees Celsius
  • nausea
  • feeling unwell or tired
  • joint pain
  • dizziness

Very rarely, you may experience a severe allergic reaction.

"DTP" vaccine refers to "Diphtheria, tetanus and whooping cough combination vaccines"

Commonside effects may include:

  • pain, redness and swelling at the injection site
  • mild fever of 37 to 38 degrees Celsius
  • headache
  • feeling unwell
  • joint pain
  • babies receiving the vaccine may become grizzly and unsettled

very rare, other side effects may include:

  • a severe allergic reaction to the vaccine
  • seizure in young children due to high fever
  • babies may experience a limp and unresponsive episode (hypotonic-hypo responsive episode) which can occur one to 48 hours after vaccination.

Common side effectsmay include:

  • muscle aches
  • pain, redness and swelling at the injection site
  • mild fever of 37-38 degreesCelsius.

Rarely, you may experience a severe allergic reaction to the vaccine.

Common side effectsmay include:

  • diarrhoea, which can occur within seven days
  • vomiting, which can occur within seven days.

Very rarely, other side effects may include:

  • intussusceptionafter the first or second dose
  • a severe allergic reaction to the vaccine.

Common side effects mayinclude:

  • pain, redness and swelling at the injection site
  • mild fever of 37-38 degrees Celsius
  • irritability, drowsiness and decreased appetite.

Very rarely, you may experience a severe allergic reaction to the vaccine.

HPV refers to Human papillomavirus

Common side effectsmay include:

  • mild to moderate pain, redness and swelling at the injection site
  • a mild fever of 37-38 degrees Celsius
  • feeling tired
  • dizziness
  • mild headaches
  • fainting
  • nausea.

Very rarely, you may experience a severe allergic reaction to the vaccine.

MMR vaccine refers to Measles, mumps and rubella (MMR) combination vaccine.

Common side effects

  • pain, redness and swelling at the injection site
  • fever after 7-10 days
  • moderate or a high fever in children up to 39 degrees Celsius or above
  • generalised faint rash (non infectious) five to 12 days later
  • head cold and/or a runny nose
  • a cough
  • puffy eyes
  • swollen glands.

Althoughrare or very rare, other side effects may include:

  • seizure due to high fever
  • bruising or bleeding (thrombocytopenia)
  • inflammation of the brain (encephalitis)
  • a severe allergic (anaphylactic) reaction to the vaccine.

People with egg allergies can safely receive the MMR and MMRV vaccine

MMRV refers to Measles, mumps, rubella and varicella (MMRV) combination vaccine

Common side effects:

  • pain, redness and swelling at the injection site
  • moderate or a high fever - in children up to 39 degrees Celsius or above
  • generalised faint rash (non infectious) five to 12 days later
  • pustular rash five to 26 days later (two to five lesions) usually at injection site, occasionally elsewhere on the body
  • head cold and/or a runny nose
  • cough and/or puffy eyes
  • swollen glands.

Althoughrare or very rare, other side effects may include:

  • seizure due to high fever
  • bruising or bleeding (thrombocytopenia)
  • inflammation of the brain (encephalitis)
  • a severe allergic (anaphylactic) reaction to the vaccine.

People with egg allergies can safely receive the MMRand MMRVvaccine

HIB vaccine refers to Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) containing vaccines

Common side effectsmay include:

  • pain, redness and swelling at the injection site
  • mild fever of 37-38 degrees Celsius
  • feeling unsettled or irritable
  • drowsiness.

Very rarely, you may experience a severe allergic reaction to the vaccine.

Meningococcal ACWY vaccine can protects against four types of meningococcal infection, the A, C, W and Y types.

Common effects mayinclude:

  • pain, redness and swelling at the injection site
  • mild fever of 37-38 degrees Celsius
  • fever up to 39 degrees Celsius or above in young children following the meningococcal B vaccine, Bexsero
  • feeling unsettled or irritable
  • reduced appetite
  • headaches
  • drowsiness
  • nausea.

Very rarely, a severe allergic reaction to the vaccine.

Learn more about vaccines Do you know HPV ? Occupation vaccines here

Common side effects may include:

  • pain, redness and swelling at the injection site
  • mild fever of 37-38 degrees Celsius
  • nausea
  • feeling unwell or tired
  • joint pain
  • dizziness

Very rarely, you may experience a severe allergic reaction.

"},{"eael_adv_tabs_tab_title":"DTP vaccines","_id":"37914d4","eael_adv_tabs_tab_show_as_default":"inactive","eael_adv_tabs_icon_type":"icon","eael_adv_tabs_tab_title_icon_new":{"value":"","library":""},"eael_adv_tabs_tab_title_image":{"url":"http://betterimmunity.ga/wp-content/plugins/elementor/assets/images/placeholder.png"},"eael_adv_tabs_text_type":"content","eael_adv_tabs_tab_content":"

"DTP" vaccine refers to "Diphtheria, tetanus and whooping cough combination vaccines"

Common side effects may include:

  • pain, redness and swelling at the injection site
  • mild fever of 37 to 38 degrees Celsius
  • headache
  • feeling unwell
  • joint pain
  • babies receiving the vaccine may become grizzly and unsettled

very rare, other side effects may include:

  • a severe allergic reaction to the vaccine
  • seizure in young children due to high fever
  • babies may experience a limp and unresponsive episode (hypotonic-hypo responsive episode) which can occur one to 48 hours after vaccination.
"},{"eael_adv_tabs_tab_show_as_default":"inactive","eael_adv_tabs_icon_type":"icon","eael_adv_tabs_tab_title_icon_new":{"value":"","library":""},"eael_adv_tabs_tab_title_image":{"url":"http://betterimmunity.ga/wp-content/plugins/elementor/assets/images/placeholder.png"},"eael_adv_tabs_tab_title":"Polio","eael_adv_tabs_text_type":"content","eael_adv_tabs_tab_content":"

Common side effects may include:

  • muscle aches
  • pain, redness and swelling at the injection site
  • mild fever of 37-38 degrees Celsius.

Rarely, you may experience a severe allergic reaction to the vaccine.

","_id":"0b2f663"},{"eael_adv_tabs_tab_show_as_default":"inactive","eael_adv_tabs_icon_type":"icon","eael_adv_tabs_tab_title_icon_new":{"value":"","library":""},"eael_adv_tabs_tab_title_image":{"url":"http://betterimmunity.ga/wp-content/plugins/elementor/assets/images/placeholder.png"},"eael_adv_tabs_tab_title":"Rotavirus","eael_adv_tabs_text_type":"content","eael_adv_tabs_tab_content":"

Common side effects may include:

  • diarrhoea, which can occur within seven days
  • vomiting, which can occur within seven days.

Very rarely, other side effects may include:

  • intussusception after the first or second dose
  • a severe allergic reaction to the vaccine. 
","_id":"c070be3"},{"eael_adv_tabs_tab_show_as_default":"inactive","eael_adv_tabs_icon_type":"icon","eael_adv_tabs_tab_title_icon_new":{"value":"","library":""},"eael_adv_tabs_tab_title_image":{"url":"http://betterimmunity.ga/wp-content/plugins/elementor/assets/images/placeholder.png"},"eael_adv_tabs_tab_title":"Pneumococcal","eael_adv_tabs_text_type":"content","eael_adv_tabs_tab_content":"

Common side effects may include:

  • pain, redness and swelling at the injection site
  • mild fever of 37-38 degrees Celsius
  • irritability, drowsiness and decreased appetite.

Very rarely, you may experience a severe allergic reaction to the vaccine.

","_id":"162c7fd"},{"eael_adv_tabs_tab_show_as_default":"inactive","eael_adv_tabs_icon_type":"icon","eael_adv_tabs_tab_title_icon_new":{"value":"","library":""},"eael_adv_tabs_tab_title_image":{"url":"http://betterimmunity.ga/wp-content/plugins/elementor/assets/images/placeholder.png"},"eael_adv_tabs_tab_title":"HPV vaccine","eael_adv_tabs_text_type":"content","eael_adv_tabs_tab_content":"

HPV refers to Human papillomavirus 

Common side effects may include:

  • mild to moderate pain, redness and swelling at the injection site
  • a mild fever of 37-38 degrees Celsius
  • feeling tired
  • dizziness
  • mild headaches
  • fainting
  • nausea.

Very rarely, you may experience a severe allergic reaction to the vaccine.

","_id":"d7b98cf"},{"eael_adv_tabs_tab_show_as_default":"inactive","eael_adv_tabs_icon_type":"icon","eael_adv_tabs_tab_title_icon_new":{"value":"","library":""},"eael_adv_tabs_tab_title_image":{"url":"http://betterimmunity.ga/wp-content/plugins/elementor/assets/images/placeholder.png"},"eael_adv_tabs_tab_title":"MMR vaccine","eael_adv_tabs_text_type":"content","eael_adv_tabs_tab_content":"

MMR  vaccine refers to Measles, mumps and rubella (MMR) combination vaccine.

Common side effects

  • pain, redness and swelling at the injection site
  • fever after 7-10 days
  • moderate or a high fever in children up to 39 degrees Celsius or above
  • generalised faint rash (non infectious) five to 12 days later
  • head cold and/or a runny nose
  • a cough
  • puffy eyes
  • swollen glands.

Although rare or very rare, other side effects may include:

  • seizure due to high fever
  • bruising or bleeding (thrombocytopenia)
  • inflammation of the brain (encephalitis)
  • a severe allergic (anaphylactic) reaction to the vaccine.

People with egg allergies can safely receive the MMR and MMRV vaccine

","_id":"cf35464"},{"eael_adv_tabs_tab_show_as_default":"inactive","eael_adv_tabs_icon_type":"icon","eael_adv_tabs_tab_title_icon_new":{"value":"","library":""},"eael_adv_tabs_tab_title_image":{"url":"http://betterimmunity.ga/wp-content/plugins/elementor/assets/images/placeholder.png"},"eael_adv_tabs_tab_title":"MMRV vaccine","eael_adv_tabs_text_type":"content","eael_adv_tabs_tab_content":"

MMRV refers to Measles, mumps, rubella and varicella (MMRV) combination vaccine

Common side effects:

  • pain, redness and swelling at the injection site
  • moderate or a high fever - in children up to 39 degrees Celsius or above
  • generalised faint rash (non infectious) five to 12 days later
  • pustular rash five to 26 days later (two to five lesions) usually at injection site, occasionally elsewhere on the body
  • head cold and/or a runny nose
  • cough and/or puffy eyes
  • swollen glands.

Although rare or very rare, other side effects may include:

  • seizure due to high fever
  • bruising or bleeding (thrombocytopenia)
  • inflammation of the brain (encephalitis)
  • a severe allergic (anaphylactic) reaction to the vaccine.

People with egg allergies can safely receive the MMR and MMRV vaccine

","_id":"743451c"},{"eael_adv_tabs_tab_show_as_default":"inactive","eael_adv_tabs_icon_type":"icon","eael_adv_tabs_tab_title_icon_new":{"value":"","library":""},"eael_adv_tabs_tab_title_image":{"url":"http://betterimmunity.ga/wp-content/plugins/elementor/assets/images/placeholder.png"},"eael_adv_tabs_tab_title":"HIB vaccine","eael_adv_tabs_text_type":"content","eael_adv_tabs_tab_content":"

HIB vaccine refers to Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) containing vaccines

Common side effects may include:

  • pain, redness and swelling at the injection site
  • mild fever of 37-38 degrees Celsius
  • feeling unsettled or irritable
  • drowsiness.

Very rarely, you may experience a severe allergic reaction to the vaccine.

","_id":"6847b40"},{"eael_adv_tabs_tab_show_as_default":"inactive","eael_adv_tabs_icon_type":"icon","eael_adv_tabs_tab_title_icon_new":{"value":"","library":""},"eael_adv_tabs_tab_title_image":{"url":"http://betterimmunity.ga/wp-content/plugins/elementor/assets/images/placeholder.png"},"eael_adv_tabs_tab_title":"Meningococcal","eael_adv_tabs_text_type":"content","eael_adv_tabs_tab_content":"

Meningococcal ACWY vaccine can protects against four types of meningococcal infection, the A, C, W and Y types.

Common effects may include:

  • pain, redness and swelling at the injection site
  • mild fever of 37-38 degrees Celsius
  • fever up to 39 degrees Celsius or above in young children following the meningococcal B vaccine, Bexsero®
  • feeling unsettled or irritable
  • reduced appetite
  • headaches
  • drowsiness
  • nausea.

Very rarely, a severe allergic reaction to the vaccine.

item.title: Vaccination for Work
item.dc:creator: mzho0025
item.content:encoded:
Occupational
Immunisations

Extra vaccination you might need for work

Working in certain jobs increases your exposure to some vaccine-preventable diseases. If you are working with vulnerable people, such as in health care, you may be exposed to and infect otherswith disease.

Specific vaccination recommendations for healthcare workers, childcare workers, laboratory workers, people who work with animals, and others.

Check below to find out whether you need some extra vaccinations.

Healthcare workers

  • hepatitis B
  • influenza
  • MMR (if non-immune see Measles)
  • pertussis (dTpa [diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis])
  • varicella (if non-immune see Varicella)
  • additional:hepatitis A vaccine and BCG(bacille CalmetteGurin) vaccine

People who work in childhood education and care

  • influenza
  • MMR(if non-immune see Measles)
  • pertussis (dTpa)
  • varicella (if non-immune see Varicella)

Carers

  • hepatitis A
  • hepatitis B
  • influenza
  • MMR(if non-immune see Measles)
  • varicella (if non-immune see Varicella)

Emergency and essential services workers

  • hepatitis B
  • influenza
  • tetanus (dT or dTpa)
  • hepatitis B
  • influenza
  • meningococcal disease (MenACWY [quadrivalent meningococcal conjugate] and MenB [meningococcal B])
  • MMR (if non-immune see Measles)
  • tetanus (dT or dTpa)
  • other vaccine-preventable diseases relevant to deployment

Laboratory workers

  • Anthrax
  • Diphtheria (dTor dTpa)
  • Q fever
  • Japanese encephalitis
  • Rabies
  • Meningococcal (MenACWY and MenB)
  • Inactivated poliovirus (IPV)
  • Typhoid
  • Smallpox
  • Yellow fever

People who work with specific communities

  • People who work with specific communities should be up to date with routinely recommended vaccines for adults, such as dT-containing and MMRvaccines. See also Table. Catch-up schedule for people 10 years of age (for vaccines recommended on a population level)in Catch-up vaccination.
  • Workers who live in, or make frequent visits to, remote Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities in the Northern Territory, Queensland, South Australia and Western Australia are recommended to receive hepatitis A vaccine.
  • Workers assigned to the outer Torres Strait Islands for a total of 30 days or more during the wet season are recommended to receive Japanese encephalitisvaccine.

People who work with animals

  • influenza
  • Q fever
  • rabies vaccine (if you cantact with bats)

Other people exposed to human tissue, blood, body fluids or sewage

  • hepatitis B vaccine
  • hepatitis A
  • tetanus (dTor dTpa)
  • dT-containing and MMRvaccines

See more

Please visit :

Vaccination for people at occupational risk
